docs.abstract: Arin Arbus and John Douglas Thompson are collaborating on their fifth play, a Theater for a New Audience production that begins previews Saturday.
docs.snippet: Arin Arbus and John Douglas Thompson are collaborating on their fifth play, a Theater for a New Audience production that begins previews Saturday.
docs.lead_paragraph: More than 25 years later, John Douglas Thompson still remembers the summer heat that made him sweat beneath his costume. He remembers lines, too, that have been stored in his brain ever since — like the “Hath not a Jew eyes” speech, in which his character, the moneylender Shylock, asserts his own humanity.

headline.main: Artistically in Sync, and Reunited for ‘The Merchant of Venice’

docs.abstract: The franchise has always portrayed the police as flawed but ultimately good. The latest spinoff does away with that ambivalence.
docs.snippet: The franchise has always portrayed the police as flawed but ultimately good. The latest spinoff does away with that ambivalence.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you were going to watch a police procedural — which, for the record, I don’t particularly recommend — you could do worse than NBC’s “Law & Order” franchise. Across 32 years and more than 1,200 episodes, the original series and its six American spinoffs have offered a gentle critique of law enforcement, presenting a parade of flawed individuals navigating a byzantine justice system. Detectives are stymied by bureaucrats and squabble with lunkhead patrol officers, who reliably contaminate crime scenes. Idealistic prosecutors grow disillusioned and leave for nonprofit work. And yet the franchise still hinges on a lesser-of-two-evils logic: The institutions may be imperfect, and the cops imperfect, but their vocation is, by definition, good. There are always more victims to avenge, and none better equipped to do it than the New York Police Department.

headline.main: ‘Law & Order’ Is Having an Identity Crisis

docs.abstract: Five other people were wounded in the shooting, which the police said “appeared to be a confrontation between armed protesters and an armed homeowner.”
docs.snippet: Five other people were wounded in the shooting, which the police said “appeared to be a confrontation between armed protesters and an armed homeowner.”
docs.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — A deadly weekend shooting in Portland at a protest against police killings left one person dead and five others wounded, raising tensions once again among the city’s social justice activists.

headline.main: One Dead in Shooting at Portland Protest Against Police Violence
headline.print_headline: 1 Dead and 5 Wounded in Portland at Protest Against Police Killings

byline.original: By Sergio Olmos, Austin Ramzy and Melina Delkic

docs.abstract: Missteps by various officials put a Tennessee woman on a collision course with the law. Supporters say the sentence underscores racial disparities in voter fraud cases.
docs.snippet: Missteps by various officials put a Tennessee woman on a collision course with the law. Supporters say the sentence underscores racial disparities in voter fraud cases.
docs.lead_paragraph: A Black woman who was sentenced last week to six years and one day in prison for trying to register to vote in 2019 despite having a felony conviction says she was the victim of complicated voting laws in Tennessee that appeared to confuse even election officials.

headline.main: Black Woman’s Bid to Regain Voting Rights Ends With a 6-Year Prison Sentence

docs.abstract: Julian Shapiro-Barnum interviews kids for his social media sensation “Recess Therapy.”
docs.snippet: Julian Shapiro-Barnum interviews kids for his social media sensation “Recess Therapy.”
docs.lead_paragraph: Julian Shapiro-Barnum brims with creative energy, often scribbling ideas for new projects in his Moleskine the way others might add items to a shopping list. And though he graduated in 2021 from the B.F.A. acting program at Boston University, he said he’s never wanted fame.

headline.main: In Search of the Meaning of Life? Meet Me at the Monkey Bars.

docs.abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
docs.snippet: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
docs.lead_paragraph: Our nonfiction recommendations this week take you from medieval manuscripts to Covid-era domestic arrangements; and from the birth of American transcendentalism in Concord, Mass., to the death of a latter-day American transcendentalist in the Parvati Valley of northern India. We also recommend a book that explores English’s role as the world’s dominant language and, in fiction, new novels by Julie Otsuka, Sarah Manguso, Paul Vidich and more. Happy reading.

headline.main: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
headline.print_headline: Staff Picks From the Book Review

docs.abstract: Pandemic misery has swelled the ranks of a right-wing protest.
docs.snippet: Pandemic misery has swelled the ranks of a right-wing protest.
docs.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — When I asked Matthew Wall, a 36-year-old electrician from Manitoba, what brought him to this city, which has been overwhelmed by a giant protest encampment, he answered with one word: “Mushrooms.” Searching for his purpose in life, he said, he went on a psychedelic spiritual journey and had an image of the Freedom Convoy, a demonstration against Covid rules that has converged on the Canadian capital with trucks and other large vehicles.

headline.main: The Giddy, Terrifying Siege of Ottawa
headline.print_headline: The Giddy, Terrifying Siege of Ottawa

docs.abstract: Anti-vaccine economic vandalism and the right-wingers who love it.
docs.snippet: Anti-vaccine economic vandalism and the right-wingers who love it.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Sunday the Canadian police finally cleared away anti-vaccine demonstrators who had been blocking the Ambassador Bridge between Detroit and Windsor, a key commercial route that normally carries more than $300 million a day in international trade. Other bridges are still closed, and part of Ottawa, the Canadian capital, is still occupied.

headline.main: When ‘Freedom’ Means the Right to Destroy
headline.print_headline: When ‘Freedom’ Means the Right To Vandalize

docs.abstract: Paul Bettany and Jeremy Pope give memorable performances as the odd couple artists in Anthony McCarten’s new play, “The Collaboration.”
docs.snippet: Paul Bettany and Jeremy Pope give memorable performances as the odd couple artists in Anthony McCarten’s new play, “The Collaboration.”
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Opposite art world titans attract in “The Collaboration,” a new play that opened Thursday at the Young Vic Theater here. Chronicling the creative partnership between Andy Warhol and Jean-Michel Basquiat during the 1980s, Anthony McCarten’s play offers bravura performances from Paul Bettany and Jeremy Pope as the two cultural icons.

headline.main: Review: Conversation and Conflict, as Warhol Meets Basquiat

docs.abstract: Todd Gitlin never left the left.
docs.snippet: Todd Gitlin never left the left.
docs.lead_paragraph: There’s an indelible scene in Todd Gitlin’s 1987 book “The Sixties: Years of Hope, Days of Rage,” in which he and other leaders of Students for a Democratic Society — the leading organization of what was called the New Left — meet with old guard democratic socialists from the journal Dissent. The encounter is worthy of a play; it’s pregnant with both unfulfilled longing for connection and exasperated contempt. “We were scarred, they untouched,” wrote Dissent’s founding editor, Irving Howe. “We bore marks of ‘corrosion and distrust,’ they looked forward to clusterings of fraternity.”

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: The Sixties: Years of Hope, Days of Rage (Book)
